thread.title_full: App that tracks walking aims to prevent falls in older people - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Alkira Reinfrank
title: App that tracks walking aims to prevent falls in older people - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: University of Canberra 2617 
The way you walk is almost as unique as your fingerprint, but did you know just how much your gait can say about your body? 
A researcher at the University of Canberra is hoping to record the gait of older people to produce an early warning system phone app, which could predict and potentially prevent people from falling. 
PhD student Hafsa Ismail is using inexpensive video cameras to research and record how balance and the way people walk changes with age. 
Currently the only way to measure someone's gait accurately is to use expensive and bulky "force-plate" technology. 
But Ms Ismail hopes her research means she can develop a phone app to enable older people to track their walk, allowing them to predict and ultimately prevent falls from happening. 
The app would make it easier for people to know when they should seek medical advice, if their balance or walk changes dramatically. 
"I'd like to see this system installed in aged care facilities, where people could be instantly assessed, while walking to get their meals three times a day," she said. 
"Their carers could be alerted when their walk deteriorates." More participants needed 
Judith Wimborne decide to take part in the study after a recent fall. 
"I had had one trip which was quite serious, I injured my arm and I thought I don't like that, I don't want to do that again," she said. 
"So if you can get some warning of the fact that you are more likely to fall, then you can take steps to avoid that. 
"Nobody wants to fall and hopefully this is going to help us along that line." 
The study is still recruiting people over the age of 50 to be involved. What do participants have to do? 
The research involves people participating in a quick walking and balance test that is filmed and repeated three times over the course of nine months. 
The time gap means any changes in gait can be detected. 
"I am currently combining the two methods, a traditional force-plate and the videos to compare the data and see the correlations that can be drawn to establish a ground truth," Ms Ismail said. Photo: Researcher Hafsa Ismail hopes to develop an app to help track changes in people's walks. (ABC News: Alkira Reinfrank) 
"The research looks at the movement of participants' legs, but also at how their torso moves or sways as they walk. 
"I'm hoping that by comparing the data, we can spot changes in the video that relate to what the force-plate is detecting. Then we can begin to program computers to analyse these videos looking for similar changes." 
If the data recorded from the videos correlates with the data from the traditional force-plate method, work can begin producing a low-cost and portable technology to track gait. 
Study supervisor Roland Goecke hoped an app or computer program could be developed within the next three years. 
"This is a really fascinating point in time now, where technology has become so ubiquitous and so cheap that we can really use it in everyday life," he said. 
"This is a fascinating crossover between health care and technology." 
If you would like to be involved in the study email Ms Ismail at Hafsa.Ismail@canberra.edu.au
